courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Introduction to Business
courses.description: This course aims at providing an introduction to the general concepts of business. It describes the economic, political, social and cultural environment in which managers and organizations function. Major topics include: the framework of business, the basic business functions, managerial functions and other selected business considerations.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To discuss the basic concepts in business and the business environment in which firms operates
To understand business management processes and the role of managers in contemporary organizations
To learn basic managerial skills and to conduct case analysis
To develop conceptual skills and analytical framework to analyze current business issues
courses.course_syllabus:
The Concept of Business and Business Environment
Basic Economics and Economic Systems
Business in Global Market
Business Ethics and Corporate Social Responsibility
Entrepreneurship and Business Ownership
Management Functions and Processes
Organizational Design and Culture
Motivation and Teamwork
Human Resource Management
Marketing Fundamentals
Product and Price
Distribution and Promotion
Information Technology and E-business
Basic Concepts in Accounting and Finance
courses.feedback_evaluation: Provide marks and comments on students’ tests and assignments, and feedback for in-class discussion
courses.required_readings:
Nickels, W.G., McHugh, J.M., and McHugh, S.M. 2010. Understanding Business, 9th Edition, New York: McGraw-Hill.

Ebert, R. J. and Griffin R.W. 2011. Business Essentials. 8th Edition. Boston: Pearson.
courses.recommended_readings: Additional readings will be introduced as the topics are discussed.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Management

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description:
This introductory course in management will focus in the discussions of the four major functions of modern management, namely, planning, organizing, leading, and controlling. We will also try to learn to appreciate the art and science of management.
Moreover, there are four special topics in modern management in this course, namely, Communication, Decision Making, Management of International Business, and Entrepreneurship.
This is a first course in management. Like many other first courses, this course is a survey of basic functions in the subject—management. Many subsequent courses in your major will build on the concepts that you come across in this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course,

a. You will be able to describe the major features of a business organization and the environments in which it operates.
b. You will be able to describe and analyze the managerial roles and the four major management functions, i.e., Planning, Organizing, Leading, and Controlling.
c. You will learn the process of communications in the individual level as well as organizational level.
d. You will learn the process and traps of decision making. You will also learn techniques to make more effective decisions.
e. You will understand such international businesses topics as cross cultural business, economic systems in the world, entry modes, and others.
f. You will appreciate the characteristics of entrepreneurs and the process of entrepreneurship, including but not limited to idea generations, justifications, and development of business plans.
g. You will learn to apply the management concepts in the real life business situations in order to diagnose the problems, recommend solutions and achieve organizational effectiveness, and
h. You will also learn to develop the knowledge and skills of management functions in order to work as an effective and efficient manager in their future career.
courses.course_syllabus:
Teaching Schedule

Week Topics
1 Introduction
2 Planning—Business Environments
A basic understanding of the macro and micro environments
3 Planning—Introduction to Planning and Goal Setting
4 Planning—Strategic Management
5 Organizing—Organizational Design and Organizational Structure
6 Organizing—Human Resources Management
7 Leading—Leadership
8 Leading—Motivation
9 Controlling—Quality and Performance
10 Special Topics—Communication
11 Special Topics—Decision Making
12 Special Topics—Management of International Business
13 Special Topics—Entrepreneurship

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: The Founder’s Journey: Entrepreneurial Mindset and Design Thinking

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: Having an entrepreneurial mindset helps understand how to develop an idea and yield innovative solutions. From the perspective of a problem-solver, this course aims to introduce design thinking as an iteractive process of value creation through opportunity recognition and implementation. This course will focus on how entrepreneurs construct and assemble opportunities in the innovative process. This course will also cover entrepreneurial ideation and implementation by addressing what entrepreneurs do in practice to turn inductive insights into reality. The ‘think out of a box’ style and employing design-based techniques are critical for students who not only know how to solve problems but know what problems to solve.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Recognize the needs for and significance of design thinking.
2. Cultivate an entrepreneurial mindset and utilize design thinking to generate innovate ideas.
3. Analyze and synthesize user research, market analytics, prototype testing, and business model validation to generate solutions.
4. Articulate a new concept or initiative in an effective and compelling manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of design thinking
2. Defining and visualizing challenges
3. Planning and identifying insights
4. Developing criteria and brainstorming
5. Developing concepts and creating napkin pitches
6. Assumption testing and prototyping

2. Students will have feedback from course teacher on assignments and project

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Managing Human Capital
courses.description: Human capital is an essential resource in organizations. Identifying, attracting, recruiting, retaining, and motivating human capital is critical for organizational success. Drawing on behavioral science concepts and theories, we examine topics including job analysis, manpower planning, recruitment, training and development, performance management, compensation and motivation, benefit, employee relations, and employee security and safety.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 or MGNT1010 or 1020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the theoretical knowledge and concepts of human capital management
2. Analyze and apply the main theories and concepts in examining organizatinal human capital problems, including Hong Kong and other countries
3. Develop human capital-related skills including critical thinking, oral and written communication skills for future general managers.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to Human Capital Management
• Job analysis
• Manpower planning
• Recruitment and Selection
• Training and Development
• Performance Management
• Compensation and Benefits
• Labor Relations

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: NUvention: New Venture Creation
courses.description:
This course is designed to introduce students to the creation of new venture and the management of new ventures. It is for students wanting to become entrepreneurs, or to pursue a career in investment in ventures (such as angels and VC firms), or simply to work in companies after equipping themselves with the knowledge of the fundaments of the path to catapult a business and see how their company will fair in the medium to long run. It also touches on the challenges of entrepreneurial businesses moving beyond start-up and enter the growth stage.
After finishing this course, students are expected to have a good understanding on key issues such as how a new product/service should be created/formulated, business planning, market identification, business/revenue model, execution path and hurdles, how to write, present and pitch an eye-catching investment proposal. They would also be alert of the need to create systems and a professional organization responsive to changes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the key aspects of a venture-based business and the roles of other stakeholders in creating a new venture.
2. Be aware of the potential challenges and dilemma in new venture operations.
3. Analyze different business situations where entrepreneurial opportunities are present or possible.
4. Develop compelling business models and business plans aimed at raising external financing.
5. Collaborate with others to develop a business plan which can guide the start-up process.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Go-to-Market strategy
2. Feasibility analysis
3. Business model canvas
4. Business plan and other communication tools
5. Market analysis and marketing strategy
6. Financial planning and budgeting
7. Fund-raising and pitching

2. Students will have feedback from course teacher on assignments and project

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Introduction to International Business
courses.description: This course studies the nature, form and scope of international business. Topics include foreign environment and major international business activities, such as exporting, direct investment, licensing and other contractual arrangements. Management strategies concerning production, marketing, human resource, and finance in an international context will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MGNT2511 and/or 2512
courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning Outcome:
• Understand concepts and theories in international business and outline the environment in which international business activities are conducted
• Develop skills and applying those concepts and theories to understanding various global business management situations
• Develop critical thinking, oral and written communication skills
• Achieve Program Learning Goal #4 (the ability to propose strategies in a global environment)
courses.course_syllabus:
Four core themes:
1)Introduction to Global Business environment
2)National Business Environment – Political, Cultural, and Economics and Financial System
3)International Trade, Investment, and Financial System – FDI, Financial Markets, Monetary System
4) Managing International Business & Management – International HR & Marketing. Market Penetration and Modes of Entry, Strategy and Organizations

\*\* The instructor reserves the right to make appropriate changes concerning the addition and deletion of topics.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Global Experiential Learning I
courses.description:
The Global Experiential Learning (GEL) course engages students in transformative global business education through self-reflection, intercultural engagement, dialogue, and service learning that will give them deeper understanding of global business and an uplifting of global experience. The two-part GEL course sequence involves students in a cycle of receiving, experiencing, reflecting, and formulating concepts that in turn guide the understanding of live global experiences. In all, the GEL courses will fully engage students in apprehending global business knowledge through a concrete experience, deriving understanding through reflective observation, comprehending global business knowledge through abstract conceptualization, and transforming global business knowledge through active experimentation.
The GEL course emphasizes the integration of academic contents and experiences of global business. Part I is a one-credit online course that disseminates fundamental concepts and frameworks of country differences, international trade, cross-border business activities, and operation of multinational enterprises. Upon completion of Part I, students can continue to take Part II, which is another one-credit course focusing on live global learning experiences. The global experiences can be categorized into outbound (e.g., term-time exchange, study trips, leadership-themed or citizenship themed international internships, overseas service trips) and inbound (e.g. local leadership-themed or citizenship themed internships or management consulting projects in multinational corporations or firms with strong global orientation). For those students who are not able to go out, they can choose to engage inbound GEL, e.g. internships at local or foreign MNCs in Hong Kong, or consulting projects on global business. For students who cannot fulfill either the outbound or inbound and have an urgency to graduate, the department may arrange study trips from time to time. With periodic guidance of the instructor, students independently reflect on and formulate concepts relating directly to their GEL. Upon completion of the global expedition, students will be evaluated on their reflection, conceptualization, and experimentation of GEL.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MGNT2510
courses.course_attributes:
Experiential Learning Course
Virtual Teaching & Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Understand concepts and theories in international business and outline the environment in which international business activities are conducted
• Develop skills and applying those concepts and theories to understanding various global business management situations
• Develop critical thinking, oral and written communication skills
• The ability to propose strategies in a global environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
Four Core Themes:
1)Introduction to Global Business environment
2) International Business Environment – Political, Cultural, and Economic and Financial System
3)International Trade, Investment, and Financial System – FDI, Financial Markets, Monetary System
4) Managing Global Business & Multinational Corporation Management

Simultaneously taking MGNT2511 and MGNT2512 will only be allowed for urgency of graduation.
Applications will be reviewed case by case.
Application for course exemption will be reviewed by the Department of Management case by case.

2. Students will have feedback from course teacher on assignments and project.
courses.required_readings: Reading materials will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings: Additional readings will be introduced as the topics are discussed.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Legal Environment, Corporate Social Responsibility and Business Ethics
courses.description:
Firms/organizations are faced with increasingly complex environments today. On the one hand, they have legal responsibility that their profits should be gained within the confines of law. On the other hand, firms/organizations have broader responsibilities for stakeholders other than shareholders. In spite of the traditional paradigms debating whether businesses should implement corporate social responsibility (CSR) activities to the society or not, it is now argued that firms with strategic CSR activities would enable them to formulate better business strategies and decisions, thus enhancing competitiveness and firm performance. Firms of different nature, such as social enterprises, can also contribute to the society with both economic and social values. Thus, students have to extend their understanding of business and its environments using modern concepts of CSR.

Half of this course provides an examination of the legal environment of Hong Kong that encompasses a selection of topics in relation to business laws. Another half of the course introduces theories and concepts of CSR as well as business and professional ethics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand the legal environment and framework in Hong Kong.
2. acquire the knowledge of the important rules of business law.
3. describe the theories and concepts of corporate social responsibility and business ethics.
4. analyze CSR topics and cases, and recommend for their effective implementation.
5. formulate own standards of integrity and professionalism and contribute insight into the professional ethics and responsibilities in the future career of students.
courses.course_syllabus:
- The legal system of the Hong Kong SAR;
- Contract law (including formation of contracts, contract terms and exemption clauses, vitiating factors, discharge of contracts and the remedies for breach of contract)
- Tort law (negligence)
- Employment law (Employees/independent contractors and the rights of employees)
- And/or any other selected topics in relation to legal environment of business
- Concepts of corporate social responsibility and its importance to business performance
- Various CSR topics in relation to business, including stakeholders theory and corporate governance
- Roles of not-for-profit organizations and social enterprises
- Theories of business ethics and their applications in the workplace, including professional ethics

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Business Sustainability
courses.description: Business activities and corporate decisions are under more scrutiny from different stakeholders nowadays. Business leaders are increasingly expected to balance short- and long-term interests for economic, social and environmental sustainability and to maintain a balance between three pillars of sustainability - people, planet, and profits. This course aims to equip students with an acumen to understand the changing role of business in society, the environment, and the global economy. The course will introduce the mega trends in driving triple-bottom line strategies for present and future. Students will reflect on the core concepts and get hold of the apparatuses for responsible and sustainable business, and develop a mindset in recognizing opportunities for sustainable innovation and development.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Recognize and aware the interconnections between the economic, social, political and ecological spheres of business activity.
• Be able to assess business risks and opportunities and approach long-term business sustainability through management and optimization of resources without compromising on profitability and competitiveness.
• Gain an understanding of innovated business practices and entrepreneurial opportunities created by the “sustainability” movement.
• Develop key sustainable business strategies and tactics facilitated by ecological thinking, eco-efficiency and life cycle analysis, and technological sustainability opportunities.
• Cultivate a CSR strategic mindset and utilize life cycle thinking to prioritize sustainability effort.
• Formulate own standards of integrity and professionalism and contribute insight into the professional ethics and responsibilities in the future career of students
courses.course_syllabus:
• Principles and Concepts of Sustainability
• Climate Change and Development
• Corporate Social Responsibility
• Business Sustainability and Entrepreneurship
• Business Sustainability and Multinational Corporations
• Sustainable Strategies
• Communicating Sustainability Efforts to Stakeholders: Corporate Shared Value (CSV) and Environmental, Social, and
Governance (EGS) Reporting
• Theories of business ethics and their applications in the workplace, including professional ethics

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Creativity and Innovation Management
courses.description:
The course aims to develop “T-shaped” characters who can develop the depth of expertise in a single field (one’s major as represented by the vertical bar of the T) while acquiring the ability to communicate and collaborate with others from different disciplines (the horizontal bar of the T) to address challenges. The ability to connect horizontally is “design thinking”, which is the bridge between creativity and innovation, combining divergent and convergent modes of thinking to connect user-experience, technology and business models to create values.
Individuals equipped with “design thinking”, the ability to think as a designer, will be able to innovate, tackle complex problems and manage changes in real life situations. By acquiring a designer’s perspective in looking at the world, students can learn to appreciate what it means to “think out of a box” --- the thinking style that transcends traditional management control mindset. They can create more alternatives before they exercise their disciplines to decide on and implement those alternatives. This course is for students who not only know how to solve problems but know what problems to solve.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Identify the research methods and questions for design thinking
2. Plan and operate the research process in a strategic and effective way
3. Analyze the design behavior based on visual, verbal, and quantitative  information derived from prototypes, interviews, field observations, and  analytics.
4. Evaluate the research outcome to support design intervention for  generating news ideas and solutions
5. Present new ideas, concepts and designs from data and analysis
courses.course_syllabus:
Class Contents Hours
1. Baseline – Know Thyself
(a) Overview of the class’s learning model: )-to-O learning and co-creation using the flipped-classroom approach
(b) Know your personality profile
(c) From I-shape to T-shape and the interdisciplinary team
(d) Your first team formation
(e) Your first in-class design assignment 3 hours (workshop)
2. Introduction to Human-centered Desgin
(a) What makes a good design?
(b) Donald Norman’s view of the mental gap between designer and user
(c) UX (user experience) as focal point of design
(d) Beyond aesthetic: the rise of usability study, interaction and service design and implications for design research 3 hours(workshop)

3. The Desgin Thinking Process
(a) The IDEO’s Shopping Cart
(b) Divergent, emergent, and convergent stages of design thinking
(c) Problem-finding and problem-solving
(d) Defining the design brief 3 hours(workshop)
4. Field Visit I
(a) Sources and contexts of inquiry
(b) Collect broken UX stories
(c) Contextual inquiry of user journey & task flow
(d) Visual and audio journals/mook and texture boards/sample products, etc. (artifacts) 3 hours(field study)
5. Tools for Design Thinking Research
(a) Market research vs. user research
(b) The research, design, production, and sales chain: how are costs/values being distributed?
(c) How can you convince your boss or client to pay for the research?
(d) Discovery, interpretation, and faming tools
(e) Ideation, prototyping, and presentation tools 3 hours(workshop)

6. Storytelling for UX Design
(a) Sharing stories supported by artifacts
(b) Finding stories in data
(c) Empathy map for persona (including extreme users)
(d) Memorable scenes, objects and interactions
(e) Revenue model and monetization of UX
(f) Framing the design problem as a story (design brief) 3 hours(workshop)
7. Ideation and Constraints
(a) Understanding competition and constraints
(b) Brand positioning and BM(business model) as constraints
(c) Brand re-positioning and M re-engineering for delivery of engaging UX
(d) Visualizing the future story (people, place, things, and interactions) 3 hours(workshop)
8. Preparation for Field Validation
(a) UX and BM validation
(b) Generate interview, survey and prototype design for UX validation
(c) Mock-up of design interventation upon existing space and workflow (front-stage and back-stage included)
(d) Establish design evaluation criteria 3 hours(lab)
9. Field Visit II
(a) Field validation
(b) Document validation process 3 hours(field study)
10. Project Consolidation
(a) Integrate UX and BM validation findings
(b) The UX of an engaging pitch
(c) Scripting your presentation as a story
(d) Break-even and cost-benefit analysis
(e) Information design for management buy-in )client or boss) 3 hours(lab)
11. Final Presentation 3 hours(workshop)

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Organizational Behaviour

Major topics include framework of organizational behaviour, concepts of human behaviour, group dynamics, techniques of behavioural sciences as applied to organizational behaviour and future perspectives of organizational behaviour within the context of management.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.description: The course is designed to enable students to study communication behaviour and processes within organizational settings. It will review the history, concepts and ideologies of organizational communication as an area of study. The topics include nonverbal and verbal information flow, interpersonal, small groups and public communication systems as well as the impact of these systems on organizational effectiveness.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Human Resource Planning and Staffing
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with useful knowledge and understanding of the very important and fundamental aspects of human resource management - human resource planning and staffing. Students will be introduced to the human resource management concepts and practice by examining the following major aspects: job analysis, human resource planning, recruitment, selection and placement. With the use of role play, video presentation and case studies, students will follow the more practical aspects of the study to gain a deeper insight into the course contents.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MGNT1020
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Explain the strategic role and importance of HR planning and staffing.
• Evaluate and decide suitable recruitment and selection plans and methods for organizations.
• Analyze employment law cases in relation to organizational staffing.
• Develop effective oral and written communication skills.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Strategic HRM, organization and staffing model.
• Introduction of various recruitment methods and their evaluation.
• Identification and assessment of various selection methods, especially psychometric testing, competency-based interviewing, and assessment centre.
• Application of employment laws in organizational staffing.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Human Capital Training and Development
courses.description: This course explores the theories and skills in human capital training and development from the management point of view. The formulation and implementation of effective policies, systems and programmes for the training and development of human capital at all levels of an organization are stressed. Major topics include the objectives of training and development, formulation and implementation of training and development policies and plans, training methods, evaluation of the effectiveness of the training and development function, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MGNT1020
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. A specific knowledge in relevant training theories and their application.
2. A specific knowledge in the relationship between training and organizational strategy.
3. A specific knowledge of a typical training cycle-training needs assessment, developing training objectives, designing training programs, implementing training, and evaluating training.
4. Systematic acquisition of training skills, including but not limited to building rapport with trainees, asking questions and leading discussions, delivering training with the right voice and attitude, and tuning mere instructions into learning.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Opportunities' Catching: Strategic Insights and Analysis
courses.description:
With continuous technological disruptions, social upheavals, and environmental threats, organisations need to become more agile and adaptive to change. Amid the ongoing challenges, modern business entities need to be more sensitive to unforeseen customers’ needs caused by new market conditions. Strategic initiatives backed by user experience insights and data analytic intelligence will become indispensable for any organisation to remain competitive in the upcoming decade.
As smart, connected, and data driven products and services become more prevalent in this coming decade, knowing the sources of data and how to acquire them programmatically for further cleaning, filtering, aggregation, modelling, evaluation, visualisation, and on-demand interaction will become increasingly important.
The purpose of this course is to prepare enrolled students in becoming entrepreneur utilising the data analysis within the Lean Start-up context for visualisation of MVP, qualitative and quantitative hypothesis testing of value proposition.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students will be able to:
1. Bridge Design Thinking and Lean Startup.
2. Build data driven MVP for achieving product-market fit.
3. Clean and format data for exploratory analysis and model building.
4. Understand data visualization principles for effective communication of KPI.
5. From usability study to A/B test: Qualitative and quantitative methods for MVP validation.
6. Deploy analytics as a conversion tracking and growth hacking system.
7. Deploy analytics as product feature (e.g. dashboard) for AI and data intensive application.
8. Integrate analytics into the pitch deck to substantiate validation metrics for attaining traction.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Lean Start-up context
2. Data-driven MVP building and validation
3. Data sourcing, formatting and visualization
4. Analytics application

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Analytics for Management
courses.description: Most strategic and organizational decisions require answering the questions: Is implementing or continuing a particular initiative the best option, given both current market conditions and likely market responses to this decision? This course is management-specific analytics course which tackles two key questions at the intersection of strategy analytics – how we use data to make better strategy and management decisions and how we can ensure the decisions being made from the available data in answering the question. The course uses statistical and analytics techniques to quantify familiar issues covered in core strategy relating to entrepreneurial decisions and global management decisions. Students will learn data-driven thinking through hands-on experience with performing analyses utilising various analytical tools that not limited to statistical analysis that interpreting their results.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: DOTE2011
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire the knowledge of advanced statistics and analytics and perform data analyses in managerial decision making
2. Apply statistical and analytics knowledge in making strategy decisions relating to entrepreneurship and global business management
3. Understand the necessity to develop analytics strategy to in-line with technology strategy as well as business & corporate strategy to generate business value
4. Strike a balance between the "hardcore analytical approach" and the "soft-side decision making process" to arrive the equilibrium of effective decision recommendations
5. Able to work with consulting firms, technology partners and use the available tools and solutions to develop and implement strategic analytics projects across organization
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: From Insights to Business Value with Strategy Focus
2. Data collection: Firm-, Industry-, Country- level Analysis
3. Statistics and Analytics in strategy, entrepreneurship, and global management

Strategy Formulation: How can we use data to choose the best competitive strategy?
4. Designing Context‐Aware the strategy and desired outcome
5. Creating Strategy-Understand what to be measured and create the strategy to gauge the outcome
6. Capturing Value Through Market Positioning
7. Analytics skills & framework to support external & internal analysis (Customer, Competitor, Business Performance, Process & People)
8. Operations and Productivity enhancement
9. ROI Analytics for the Stakeholders
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
courses.required_readings: to be determined by course instructor

- HBR Collection (HBR Guide to Data Analytics Basics for Managers 2018)
- Mckinsey Analytics 2018, An Executive's Guide to AI
- HBR Selected Case Studies

- MIT Sloan Selected Articles

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Human Capital Analytics
courses.description:
Human Capital is critical to organizational effectiveness and knowing how to use data to make evidence-based human resource decisions is an important key. This course equips you with the foundational knowledge and skills of people analytics so that you are able to apply them to make decisions on recruiting, selecting, retaining, training, motivating, and appraising organizational human capital and talent. This is a hands-on course in which you learn and practice how to make sense of human resource data and metrics using different statistical tools and techniques, summarize and report findings, and make informed human resource decisions.
Students interested in more technical side or more behavioral side of research methods can take additional research methods course, such as DOTE2040 Business Analytics or MKTG3010 Marketing Research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: DSME2011
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the needs and benefits of data analysis in managing human resources
2. Acquire the knowledge of understanding HR data and predictive HR analytics
3. Apply HR analytics knowledge in analyzing HR data and making HR decisions
4. Present findings from HR analytics visually and effectively
courses.course_syllabus:
1. People Metrics and Analytics: Definitions and connection to human capital management
2. Human Resource Information Systems: Software and Tools
3. Analysis Strategies
4. Employee Attitude Survey Data Analysis: Measurement and Reliability analyses
5. Predicting Turnover
6. Predicting Employee Performance
7. Recruitment and Selection Analytics: Reliability and Validity analyses
8. Tracking the Impact of Training Interventions
9. Reporting and Decision Making from analyzing HR metrics
10. Congruence between HR profiles and business strategies

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Business Negotiations
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to help students understand the theory and processes of negotiation in a variety of settings. This course helps develop negotiation skills by addressing a variety of negotiation topics experientially by 1) preparing for and simulating a range of negotiation situations and 2) analyzing students’ negotiation outcomes and strategies. We integrate students’ experiences with negotiation theory in a weekly debrief. Readings complement the classroom experience and reinforce key messages from the experiences.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will develop the following skills:

a. Business Knowledge:
• Learn to analyze negotiation situations, including assessing the bargaining zone and understanding the motivations and interests of both sides.
• Know how to develop a strategic plan for effective negotiations, including a thorough understanding of how to create a bottom-line walk-away point (reservation price), knowledge of BATNA (best alternative to a negotiated agreement), and how to set a target.
• Understand the difference between creating and claiming value, and develop skills in both areas.
• Understand common tactics used in negotiations.
• Better understand yourself through repeated exposure to negotiation situations.
• Build confidence as a negotiator.

b. Ethical Judgment:
• Understand how to wisely and ethically select – as well as defend against – strategic maneuvers.

c. Persuasive Communication:
• Learn to frame arguments effectively and analyze other people’s motivations and interests, to be more convincing and reach better deals.

The bottom line: You should come out of this course as an analytically and intuitively savvy negotiator.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics:

1. Introduction
2. Distributive Negotiation – Fixed Pie Analysis
3. Negotiation Preparation – Go to the Balcony
4. Information Exchange – Expanding the Pie
5. Coalitions
6. Integrative Bargaining
7. Interests, Rights, & Power
8. Negotiator Personality and Biases
9. Conflict
10. Agents and Technology
11. Culture
12. Job Negotiations
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mandatory CTE.
2. Students will have feedback from course teacher on assignments and project.
courses.required_readings:
Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement without Giving In: Fisher and Ury. ISBN#: 0-14-015735-2.

Negotiation simulation cases will be used.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) The Mind and Heart of the Negotiator (7th Edition) by Thompson. ISBN#: 9781292399447.
(2) Negotiation Genius by Malhotra and Bazerman. ISBN#: 9780553384116

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Managing Social Enterprises
courses.description: Social enterprise management and social entrepreneurship involve the identification of opportunities to tackle social problems through the application of entrepreneurial principles that creates social value and effects social change. This course aims to provide students with an introduction on the tools and process of managing social enterprises and encourage students to apply creative and entrepreneurial approaches to address social problems. Apart from theoretical explorations in analyzing important concepts such as social innovation and social entrepreneurship, the course would also cover practical management skills such as creating business models and business planning to sustain a social business.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Global Enterprise Management
courses.description: One of the important trends of modern business is globalization. Organizations, particularly multinational corporations, are continuously expanding across national borders. This course focuses on multinational corporations as a context in which issues in managing the globalization of an organization are examined. This course covers both the macro and the micro aspect of global business management. The macro aspect involves the considerations of the various contexts of the host nation, including the legal, economic and cultural. The micro aspect involves the internal operating environment of the organization, including organizational culture and structure, staffing and training needs, and dealing with business partners across national borders. Regional examples will be emphasized.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Strategic Management

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

courses.description:
This course is concerned with the formulation, implementation, and evaluation of business strategies. Topics include selection of objectives, analysis and diagnosis of business environment, evaluation of strengths and weaknesses, selection of strategies, the creation of corporate identity and structure, the acquisition and development of resources, and strategy review, evaluation and control.
As a capstone course, this course is aimed to integrate the functional areas of business (e.g., accounting, finance, human resources, marketing, and operations).
This course also helps the students understand business environments, analyze and, solve the business problems from the perspective of top managers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: HTMG1010 or MGNT1020 and at least two 3000/4000 level coursees offered by the Faculty of Business Administration.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Analyze the external and internal environment as well as the competitive situations
• Identify significant strategic issues and propose strategic recommendations that are effective, efficient and realistic
• Apply the most up-to-date concepts, frameworks, and tools from all the business disciplines and synthesize them with a holistic perspective to approach business problems and solutions

• Corporate Governance

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Talent Performance Management Systems and Strategies
courses.description: This course develops students for aligning employee performance and rewards with business strategy through lectures, simulation exercises and case discussion. Topics covered in this course include aligning human resources and rewards with business strategy, effects of pay on employees’ attitudes and behaviors, valuing employees and improving performance through reward design, implementation and evaluation, designing and managing performance systems, emerging areas of reward strategy and systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MGNT1020
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Understand concepts and models underlying various employee performance, pay and reward strategies
- Apply relevant concepts of recent theoretical and research development to analyze real-world business cases
- Create an environment in which students can enhance critical thinking, synthesize new ideas and develop their interpersonal skills

courses.description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of the practices in managing staff relationship. Cases are used to illustrate the key concepts. Major topics to be discussed include: economic, political and socio-cultural background; the development of trade unionism; wage determination; the legal regulation on employment, working hours, working conditions, health and safety, and worker's compensation; system for settlements of workplace conflict; labour market and employment issues and employer-employee cooperation.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Successful completion of this course should enable students to:
1. Acquire a solid theoretical and practical perspective on various aspects of staff relationship
2. Understand the common practices in managing staff relationship
3. Identify the key factors affecting the development of staff relationship
4. Develop research, analytical, and writing skills in HRM

courses.title: Social Innovation and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Social entrepreneurship requires visionary individuals to think out of the box and create new business opportunities for mission-driven ventures. Combining innovative mindset with the application of entrepreneurial principles, mission-driven ventures could bring social, environmental as well as economic benefits to the society. This course will teach knowledge and tools so that students can facilitate their efforts and to involve in social entrepreneurship. courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Leadership Development
courses.description: This course develops students for various leadership skills necessary in the work place through flipped-learning, simulated exercises and real-world case discussion in class. Both personal and interpersonal skills are included. Personal skills include: personal-style assessment, values, goal-setting, applying emotional intelligence and stress management. Interpersonal skills include: communicating, motivating, mentoring, delegating, persuading, facilitating team work, resolving conflicts and negotiating.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 or MGNT1020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand concepts and models underlying various personal and interpersonal skills in the work place.
2. Guide students to apply effective personal and interpersonal skills to diagnose the practical management problems in the workplace and come up with proper solutions to deal with these problems.
3. Create an environment in which students can enhance self-awareness, synthesize new ideas and develop their personal strengths and interpersonal skills.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Technology and Innovation Management
courses.description:
Creating new businesses, capturing new markets and enhancing organizational effectiveness occur through improving productivity or innovation or both. New discoveries and new technologies compel both entrepreneurs and existing firms to foster innovation in order to sustain growth. This course is designed to lead the students through the tasks that are required to successfully build a business around innovation.
It examines the theory and practice of promoting and managing innovation in start-ups and existing firms. It explores the disruption innovation theory and practices in detail then provide a roadmap and framework for managers to create repeatable & predictable growth strategies and new businesses for existing firms and entrepreneurs. All other related innovation strategies will also be explored such as blue ocean strategy, technology strategy, reverse innovation and open innovation. Finally, the course is concluded by the importance to integrate innovation and follow through the strategic process including situation analysis, strategy formulation and implementation together.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are able to examine the theories and practices of promoting and managing innovation
2. Students are able to develop the skills required to become an innovator and the innovation change catalyst for a typical company
3. Students are able to apply the theories to develop and make a good proposal on the technology strategy and disruptive innovation program for a typical company.
courses.course_syllabus: Innovation Introduction (great companies may failure), Innovator's Solution (innovation is predictable), Innovator DNA (difference between typical executives and entrepreneurs; the Five Skills), An Innovation Engine(4 components of a growth factory; 90 Days program), The First Mile (develop a business idea; Idea Resume, Mini Business Plan, 4P Model), Blue Ocean & Technology Strategy (12 Disruptive technologies), Other Innovation Strategies (reverse innovation & open innovation), The Innovation Leadership & Strategy(innovation is a strategic process; roles of CEO)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
courses.required_readings: The Innovator’s Dilemma - Clayton M.Christensen
courses.recommended_readings:

4. The First Mile - Anthony Scott
5. Blue Ocean Strategy - Chan Kim
6. 12 Disruptive Technology - McKinsey Report (2013-2025)
7. Strategic Management of Technological Innovation – Melissa Schilling
8. Recommended HBR articles

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Management Consulting and Change Management
courses.description: In a rapidly changing business world that is full of uncertainty, complexity, and plurality, it is not the strongest species that survive but the ones who are most responsive or even proactive to change. This course is designed to prepare students to become effective contributors to the management consulting profession as well as to firms, either startups or established, that are facing pressures for corporate turnaround. Through real business case discussions, experience sharing by global and local consultants, and consulting projects and networking activities, students will learn the fundamentals of consulting practice, including diagnosing situations, planning and executing assignments, client management, as well as a variety of diagnostic and problem-solving techniques used in different consulting firms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 or MGNT1020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Develop an understanding of the nature and rigor of management consulting, as well as the frameworks and tools commonly used by management consultants for problem solving, business valuation, change management, and strategy execution.
2. Acquire knowledge of strategic reorientation, corporate turnaround, and change management.
3. Demonstrate problem solving, design, and other analytical skills and learn overall consulting process skills.
4. Practice and sharpen executive writing and presentation skills.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Advanced Social Entrepreneurship and Impact Investment
courses.description: Social entrepreneurship requires visionary individuals to think out of the box and create new business opportunities for mission-driven ventures. Combining innovative mindset with the application of entrepreneurial principles, mission-driven ventures could bring social, environmental as well as economic benefits to the society. To support these ventures, impact investment and venture philanthropy can provide not only the resources to support such efforts, but also impact-driven accountability and results-orientated approach. This course will teach advanced knowledge and tools as well as hands-on skills, so that students can facilitate the above efforts and, specifically, to involve in a real-life social venture partner. They will need to address the challenges, capture potential opportunities and solicit support from the eco-system to make the venture real and sustainable. The best group of students will receive funding to work with the chosen venture partner.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students are expected to:
 Understand the current landscape of the social enterprises and venture philanthropy industry (both globally and locally).
 Have acquired hands-on knowledge and skills in the social entrepreneurship, social innovation, management consulting and venture philanthropy industry through their project works.
 Have learned the ability to conduct advanced analysis of critical business issues of a social enterprise and conduct basic due diligence.
 Apply design thinking framework and tools to develop new business opportunities and offerings with positive social or environmental impacts.
 Be able to conduct research, write and present a professional business analysis proposal, including a credible proposal for fund raising.
 Have gained an understanding on a broader eco-system of the social enterprise sector, including key players such as businesses, venture philanthropist, NGOs and government agencies.
 Have demonstrated the ability to apply theoretical knowledge into real life situation.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: China Business
courses.description: In today's business world, more and more organizations and managers start to realize the importance of responsible business---business beyond economic success and also responsible for various stakeholders---in order to foster long-term, sustainable success for any organization. Another crucial trend in management today is that organizations need to know more about the micro-foundations, that is, behavioral and psychological principles and mechanisms, behind their business. These are consistent with the notion that a, if not the, key to business success is through knowing about people (e.g., customers, managers, and employees). This course is accordingly designed as a selective survey of micro organizational behavior/human resource management and particularly the applications in the Chinese context in order to promote a deep understanding of the micro-foundation of responsible business in the Chinese context. Topics include: understanding people in China (e.g., individual differences, leadership, and motivation), understanding work in China (e.g., job design and teams), and understanding well-being in China.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: MGNT1020
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students in this course are expected to:
(1) garner a solid understanding of the basic concepts and theories of responsible business and micro-foundations of business, and their real life applications in the Chinese context and
(2) obtain practical implications of the above topics in order to foster a deep understanding of responsible business in the Chinese context.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic concepts and theories of responsible business and micro-foundations of business, and their real life applications in the Chinese context.
2. Understanding people in China (e.g., individual differences, leadership, and motivation)
3. Understanding work in China (e.g., job design and teams)
4. Understanding well-being in China.
5. Practical implications of the above topics in order to foster a deep understanding of responsible business in the Chinese context.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mandatory CTE.
2. Students will have feedback from course teacher on assignments and project.
courses.required_readings: No specific textbook will be used for this course. Instead, we will use three Harvard cases and additional materials.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Japanese Business
courses.description: The goal of the course is to introduce students to an integrated understanding of Japan's business systems and strategic management of Japanese firms. This approach encourages students to learn from Japan's experience and consider implications for managers and government policy makers.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to complete the following key tasks:
1. Understand the historical and cultural context of Japanese business and management
2. Recognize implications of Japan's early (economic growth and 'bubble' economy) and recent (post-'bubble' economy, aging society) economic and social experiences
3. Identify key features of Japanese management environment and practice (innovation, entrepreneurship, human resources, international business)
4. Analyze the sustainability of Japanese business systems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The historical and cultural context of Japanese business and management

3. Japanese management environment and practice (innovation, entrepreneurship, human resources, international business)
4. Sustainability of Japanese business systems

3. Develop analytical, critical thinking and problem solving skills
4. Develop effective communication skills and ability to work with a diverse group of people
5. Acquire and apply important management skills in cross-cultural context , including adaptability, cultural awareness, and interpersonal skills
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Global Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the creation and management of new ventures in the global era. It will cover the concept of entrepreneurship, policies and other factors conducive to innovation and new venture creation, writing of business plan, and the skills to manage a new venture. Cases of new ventures around the globe and visits to local new ventures will be used to illustrate concepts and help students gain insight into new venture creation process. Students will write, under close direction, a business plan aimed for inviting investment as a requirement of the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: At least 2 2000-level or above courses in Faculty of Business Administration or Department of Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will have an understanding on how to seize an opportunity entrepreneurially from the stand-point of Hong Kong.
2. Students’ awareness of the obstacles, challenges, and dilemmas inherent in
international and global ventures in the context of Hong Kong and this region will be heightened.
3. Develop a sense in students on how to manage and finance global business ventures.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Understanding entrepreneurship and economic development; Being an entrepreneur;
3. Opportunity recognition and screening - Exercise 1: Opportunity Recognition (1-page report) / Case: "Jade-link and luxury market in China "
4. Business Model and Business Plan
5. Acquiring resources for startup - Case: "Toy2R - an action figure hobbyist turned entrepreneur"
6. Field visit to learn about incubation programmes
7. Building a startup team - Case: “Ockham Technologies”/
8. Financial resources - 5 min presentation of project ideas
9. Growth, Harvesting & Transition - Case: "TCS: An entrepreneurial air-express company in Pakistan”
10. Acquiring an Existing business Case: "Qi Tech: A Chinese Technology Firm for Sale" / Exercise 2 (negotiation)
11. Family enterprising and corporate entrepreneurship - Case: “AML – Incubating the next generation to venture”
12. Project Presentation
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Doing Business in Emerging Economies
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to business systems in emerging economies. The topic includes an overview of social, political, cultural, and economic environments in emerging economies, multinational corporations doing business in emerging economies, and emerging economy firms doing business abroad. The geographic scope spans Asia, Africa, Latin America and Eastern Europe, with a particular emphasis on ASEAN countries. Real life examples and case studies will be used to advance students’ understanding of the multifaceted realities of emerging economies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand social, cultural, political, and economic environments that characterize emerging economies.
2. Identify the institutions of emerging economies that are relevant to managers and understand how they work.
3. Analyze the challenges and opportunities presented by foreign firms doing business in emerging economies.
4. Analyze the challenges and opportunities presented by emerging economies firms doing business abroad.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understand social, cultural, political, and economic environments that characterize emerging economies.
2. Identify the institutions of emerging economies that are relevant to managers and understand how they work.
3. Analyze the challenges and opportunities presented by foreign firms doing business in emerging economies.
4. Analyze the challenges and opportunities presented by emerging economies firms doing business abroad.

Cavusgil ST, Ghauri PN, Akcal AA. 2013. Doing Business in Emerging Markets (Second Edition).
SAGE Publications Ltd

Redding G, Witt M. 2014. Oxford Handbook of Asian Business Systems. Oxford University Press.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Entrepreneurship Practicum Workshop
courses.description: The workshop-style class will offer experiential learning in multidisciplinary interaction and collaboration. The objectives are to enable students to exercise the knowledge and techniques related to entrepreneurship, starting up and innovation, and to gain hands-on experiences in using the knowledge & skills to solve real problems that present great opportunity. In a team-based learning model, students of diverse disciplines, e.g., business administration, engineering, journalism, etc. will work with on problems along a theme in the areas of, say, smart city, big data, active aging. Students will have the opportunities to experiment and implement their ideas.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand user-experience design and prototyping in practice
2. Practise the skills to work on real-life problems with people of diverse backgrounds
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning Contents Hours
1. Setting up
(a) Review “Design Thinking”
user experience (UX), technology transformation (TT), and business model (BM) to foster innovation
(b) Background and key problems on the thematic domain
(c) Facilitate the design process through divergent and convergent thinking methods and techniques in a multidisciplinary team context
(d) Manage team formation and project implementation with digital tools 3 hrs. (Lecture + Workshop)/ team teaching with domain experts of the selected theme, such as big data, active aging, bottom-of-the-pyramid medicine, financial tech, etc.
2. Managing the Design Process
(c) Use brainstorming and visualization as a means to frame and solve problems
(d) Storyboarding and role playing the user journey
(e) Build and test prototypes to expedite the learning process 3 hrs. (Lecture + Workshop)
3. System Integration and Business Model for Sustainable Innovation
(a) Validate user and customer adoption with Kickstarter, user testing, social media, and field observation
(b) Using technology (including crowd sourcing and open-innovation resources) and organization design to gain competitive and process advantages 3 hrs. (Lecture + Workshop)
4. Final Class Presentation
(a) Team presentation/Q&A
(b) Experience sharing 3 hrs. (Final Presentation)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey; evaluation of final prototype or proposal
courses.required_readings: (a) Osterwalder, A. (2010), Business Model Generation Chapter 1, John Wiley & Sons 2010.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Family Business and Wealth Management
courses.description: Family business is often ignored as the most popular organizational form in the world. Families have started many of the most successful firms in the world, owned the majority of listed firms in many nations, and upheld the best innovation, quality and brand value. While many family funds contribute significant philanthropic and investment projects, how to use the huge wealth accumulated is a growing concern for the governments and the society. This course takes a family enterprising approach to discuss the importance, diversity, complexity, and trans-generational nature of business family and family wealth. It also discusses how private banking, consulting, trust, and legal professionals can help to preserve wealth being created for the benefit of the families and that of the society at large. The course is for both students interested in a family business or a professional career, as they can learn the dynamics behind family businesses and their stakeholders.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Entrepreneurial Financing and Startup Fund-Raising
courses.description: This course is for students wanting to become entrepreneurs, or to pursue a career in investment in ventures (such as angels and VC firms), or simply to work in companies after equipping themselves with the knowledge of the fundamentals of the path to catapult a business and see how their company will fair in the medium to long run. After finishing this course, students are expected to have a good understanding on key issues such as how a new product/service should be created/formulated, business planning, market identification, business/revenue model, execution path and hurdles, how to write, present and pitch an eye-catching investment proposal.
courses.learning_outcomes: Good understanding on key issues such as how a new product/service should be created/formulated, business planning, market identification, business/revenue model, execution path and hurdles, how to write, present and pitch an eye-catching investment proposal.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Managing Human Resources
courses.description: This course helps students to understand the important human resource management issues and practices which affect organizational performance. In order to explore these issues in depth, the course will enable students to understand human behaviour in organizations. The course provides concepts and theories about the basic social-psychological processes that affect individual, interpersonal, and group behaviour in organizations. Finally, students are challenged to develop a strategic approach for managing human resources.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Leadership in Organizational Design
courses.description: In a world characterized by VUCA (Volatile, Uncertain, Complex and Ambiguous), organizational design in way that supports developing strong executive leadership is critical to organizational success. In this course we ask: What does it take to be a successful top management leader? To address this question requires a multi-faceted combination of relevant knowledge, skills and experience that will evolve over time throughout one's career. This course will explore theoretical frameworks and research findings from psychology, sociology, management studies, political science, anthropology and neuroscience. We apply these findings in a practical manner through the use of cases, group exercises, media accounts and guest speakers. The class is interactive and significant participation in discussion is expected in order to reap the full benefits. In sum, with such momentous changes happening in the VUCA world today, this course will prepare students to better understand the complexity and challenges of top management leaders.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:
• Describe and interpret some of the VUCA forces impacting our world and explore their ramifications for developing top management leaders.
• Learn conceptual frameworks for understanding the importance of organizational design, power and politics, culture, change management and corporate governance and the interrelationships among them.
• Develop and enhance leadership skills to prepare for the future.
• Identify and analyse a problem from a leadership perspective and develop a mind-set to appreciate the complex, uncertain and ambiguous nature of business problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction, course overview and leadership skills assessment
2. Strategic organizational design
3. Political pragmatics in organizations
4. Organizational culture
5. Change management
6. Corporate governance
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Corporate Governance and Corporate Social Responsibility
courses.description: This course focuses on two key and related areas aiming at sustainability by aligning interests between the firm and its stakeholders. This course aims to develop students a managerial mindset for doing good business and doing it well by introducing basic concepts and practices related to CG and CSR. The course will cover fundamental, emerging, and context-specific organizations and institutions, internal and external CG mechanisms, strategic CSR, social entrepreneurship and innovation, public/private/NGO partnership, family business, corporate fraudulence and scandals, crisis response strategies, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. develop a fundamental value system that respects different stakeholders and have a balanced and holistic view of a firm and its environment
2. lay a foundation of key concepts and practices in CG and CSR
3. enhance their awareness and analytical skills in managing complex CG and CSR issues especially in the increasingly global and digital economy
4. develop their knowledge base for effective CG system, management control, and strategic implications for sustainability
5. arouse their interest in society and keep abreast of latest development on CG and CSR
courses.course_syllabus:
- Why CSR, law and business ethics? Or, how we got where we are today
- Guidance on CSR (what are they, and how to use them)
- Stakeholders: what are they, and what role do they play
- Ethics and worldviews: Ethics in business
- Managing risk in supply chains
- Community investment: A company’s role in the community
- ESG: the financial world and CSR

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Creating Global Advantages
courses.description: This course will help prepare students planning to work in large and small firms making international business decisions and acting as an effective international manager. Topics include: strategies on internationalization process; understand different modes of entry; mergers and acquisitions; explore key strategies for international business; investigate how to interact with and work on multicultural teams, how to be an effective leader in different countries, and how to conduct international negotiations. The course will also explore key design, management, and strategy issues that multinational corporations face.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. develop an understanding of effective internationalization strategies
2. learn the pros and cons of different entry modes
3. learn about how to successfully design and manage important collaborative modes of international business like mergers and acquisitions
4. explore key strategies for international business
5. acquire an understanding of how to interact with and work on multicultural teams effectively
6. develop an understanding of complex decision making in international business
7. develop an understanding of how to be an effective leader in different countries
8. learn how to conduct international negotiations effectively
9. learn about key design, management, and strategy issues multinational corporations face
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Definitions, key strategies and cases of GILT (globalization, internationalization, localization, translation) process
(2) Future mega trends and disruptive forces under new normal and macro views of globalization after pandemic (PESTLE)
2. 1 (P) Political Order and Disorder
2. 2 (E) China – US decoupling impact on economic development
2. 3 (S) Learning for Sustainability and Green economy
2. 4 (T) Technology surge, disruptions in global value chain
2. 5 (L) Latest Legal topic regarding the patent strategies of new innovations
2. 6 (E) Education – future employment trend
(3) Theories and various new modes of entry into diverse markets (pros and cons)
(4) Cultural discrepancy and how to manage the multicultural teams
(5) International leadership, negotiation and effective ways of working for global operation
(6) Creating your own ecosystem – survival of the fittest, not smartest or sharpest

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Strategic Management for Competitive Advantage
courses.description: The course is designed to offer students with an integrative framework for formulating and implementing corporate-level and business-level strategies that help firms achieve sustainable competitive advantages. It introduces a wide variety of strategic analysis tools and adopts case-based teaching approach. The course will cover important strategic management topics such as formulating competitive strategies, corporate diversification, mergers and acquisitions, strategic alliances and networks, organizational structure and control mechanisms, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. develop an integrative and a holistic view of a firm and its internal and external environment
2. understand generic business and corporate strategies and how to choose appropriate strategy that meets environmental requirements and matches organizational resources / capabilities
3. formulate full-range strategies and implementation plans
4. develop and strengthen critical thinking, deep analytical, persuasive written and oral communication skills.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Business Model Canvas for Digital Economy
courses.description: This course aims at helping students understand basic concepts and methods of application of business models. A business model is a logical and internally consistent representation of the design and operations of a business, capturing the essence of how it will be focused and demonstrating how an interrelated set of decision variables will be addressed to create, deliver and capture value. There is a widespread recognition that competition between businesses today is not solely based on their strategies but to a large extent on innovative business models. Increasingly often, startups introduce new business models and change the dynamics of the industry and related industries. Business model innovation is focused on the design and development of new and unique business models that, by definition, challenge accepted conventions in a given industry about how to create and deliver customer value in new ways. This course will explore the range and diversity of innovative business models in the digital economy and equip students with hands on experience in developing innovative business models that capitalizes strategic opportunities given by the digitalization.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. understand and be able to explain the purpose, role and importance of business models, including the key elements of a business model and the interactions and interdependencies among the elements
2. develop capabilities to analyze and develop business model innovations that capitalize strategic opportunities given by the digitalization, evaluate their strengths and limitations, and make recommendations for improvement
3. demonstrate the ability to evaluate, design, and recommend innovative business models for entrepreneurial new ventures or businesses experiencing significant changes in their external environments
4. develop innovative business model design thinking and creativity
courses.course_syllabus:
- What is a Business Model
- Business Model Canvas
- Business Model Archetypes
1: Unbundling
2: Long-tail
3: Multi-sided market
4: Free
5: Open innovation and Network
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.

The course will heavily rely on the following book and internet sources. The list of the optional readings is provided in the References (see below).
Osterwalder, Alexander and Pigneur, Yves. 2010. Business Model Generation. Hoboken, New Jersey: John Wiley and Sons, Inc.

Students are strongly encouraged to register for Strategyzer.com where they can download a blank sheet of business model canvas and have access to other useful resources (free of charge)

iii. Cases
A number of cases are selected for building the context in which strategy formulation and implementation are assumed to occur. These cases are published in well-known business schools including Harvard, Ivey, IMD, Michigan, and INSEAD among others.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Emerging Technology and Business Innovation
courses.description: This course aims at providing a solid ground to students interested in top management and government policy issues concerning the innovation process. The course is divided into 5 main parts. The first part discusses technology at the macro level: technology's impact on industries and nations, and patterns of technological change. The second part of the class focuses on disruptive innovations–what they are, how they impact firms and industry change. The third part deals with the response of firms to disruptive innovations, including the changing basis of competition in markets. Also, the increasing returns environment is examined. The fourth part focuses on building organizations' internal capabilities to innovate and the "innovator's solution". The fifth part discusses additional topics in innovation such as entrepreneurship, and creating innovative organizations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. understand key theories, the empirical and case evidence about the theories, and some practical and personal application
2. deepen their understanding about strategic management of innovation at the macro level (technology evolution, diffusion and neglect, and government policy), the meso or middle level (industry and firm level, particularly strategic issues, new products, new product features) and the micro level (innovation projects and implementation, innovative organizations, and entrepreneurship)
courses.course_syllabus:
- World digital competitiveness and its implications to Asia
- Hype cycle of emerging technologies
- Top ten emerging technologies and their impacts to major industries
- Innovation and entrepreneurship: disruptive and collaborative approaches
- Best practices of unleashing business values from emerging technologies, innovations and entrepreneurship
- Case studies from enterprises, technology giants and start-ups
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Entrepreneusrship and Strategic Renewal
courses.description: This course aims at providing a solid ground to students interested in entrepreneurship and strategic renewal processes of the firms. In a world of innovations that keep accelerating change, formulating path-breaking innovation strategy and organizational transformation to remain competitive is an increasing imperative. Sustained competitiveness often requires entrepreneurial initiatives in startup, growing, mature or declining organizations with the purpose of instilling a strategic orientation for dynamic capabilities and competitive advantages. This course will offer fundamental concepts, models, and best practices of entrepreneurship and strategic renewal of different organizational types, at different stages of organization life span, and across different industries and countries. Emphasis will be placed on entrepreneurial opportunity recognition, organizational diagnosis, design and alignment, as well as the execution of organizational transformation and renewal.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, the students are expected to:
1. understand entrepreneurship and strategic renewal concepts, models, and best practices
2. lead entrepreneurial and strategic renewal initiatives with confidence to cope with dynamic environments
3. develop knowledge and skills for executing entrepreneurial pursuit and organizational renewal for change
4. develop an entrepreneurial and change mindset for sustainability in a dynamic and complex business environment

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Executive Challenge for Innovation
courses.description: This course aims at helping students understand the nature of challenges faced by executives in innovation management. This course uses a role-playing simulation, which is run full-time over four consecutive days (96 hours). The entire course will be conducted with students split into management teams of five students (CEO, Finance Director, Sales & Marketing Director, Operations Director, and HR Director). The management teams of students will act in response to a series of actual events surrounding the management takeover of a newly acquired firm. The course provides real-time insight into what it is like to assume managerial control of a company.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. experience the managerial control of an acquisition
2. act in response to a series of actual events surrounding the management takeover of a newly acquired firm
