courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: New Venture Management

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: This course focuses on the nature and challenges of entrepreneurial businesses as they move beyond startup and enter the growth stage. A majority of them usually sustain unique technology, business model, and other competences that other companies find it difficult to match. Yet entrepreneurial firms in the growth phase must build an organization capable of managing this growth. Besides, as other firms enter the market they need to sustain growth as the market and competitive environment changes. The entrepreneur needs to create systems and a professional organization both responsive to external change and entrepreneurial enough to continually create new businesses and products through innovative thinking.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. understand issues related to commercialization of technology, innovation, and creative ideas
2. learn the theories and concepts of growth management and expansion of new ventures
3. gain insight into the risks and challenges faced by hi-growth ventures and the entrepreneurs

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Strategic Management in Sustainability
courses.description: As an industry leader, holistic analysis and evaluation are vital. Business leaders integrate the company’s Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)/Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) strategy and long-term sustainable development goals into its business strategies and management practices. This course covers advanced and latest management strategies (including Transaction, Turnaround, and Restructuring Strategy), techniques, models and frameworks used in resolving business sustainability and execution issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Sustainable Global Business
courses.learning_outcomes: This course aims to focus on how to strategically manage firms to achieve sustainable competitive advantages. Integrating theories and practices on corporate strategic management and ESG, this course teaches students the underlying logics of strategic decision-making, conceptual models/tools and practical advice to define, evaluate and achieve sustainable business success; analyze organizations and their business environments; design and evaluate corporate and business (competitive) strategies; identify and understand the implications of environmental changes; and effectively manage strategy making, strategy implementation, and organizational change in different organizational contexts for sustainable growth and competitive advantages.
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.description: There is a growing demand for collaboration among public, private, and non-governmental organisations to tackle social and environmental wicked problems such as climate change. courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Sustainable Business Transformation: Human-Environment Systems, Frameworks and Practices
courses.description:
This course will equip the students with the essential knowledge about sustainability, proven sustainable business transformation framework and best practices to navigate the evolving landscape of sustainability in the business world.

Firstly, students will have the opportunity to deepen the understanding about sustainability by learning the critical sustainability concept such as the Couple Human-Environment Systems and ecosystem and services, which frequently display thresholds, discontinuities, and multiple-equilibrium. The difficulties that these complex behaviors pose for prediction, adaptation, monitoring and management are profound, and have received extensive attention under the rubrics of “resilience,” “vulnerability,” and “tipping points.” The course covers how institutions and culture shape human interactions with one another and the environment. Students will learn institutional challenges for sustainable development posed by the need to create or protect public goods (e.g. environmental services, “green” technologies) in the face of multiple externalities and opportunities for free-riding.

This course goes beyond theoretical concepts. Business and corporations play critical roles in driving sustainability. Understanding sustainability and drive sustainable business development is a “must” for future business success and is a transformational process requiring strategic insights, leadership and commitment. Students will acquire practical tools and strategies for driving sustainable transformation that have been proven to foster a sustainable future for businesses. In addition, students will also learn the best practices from successful leading companies locally and globally to build up practitioner skills in driving sustainable changes in the industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Sustainable Global Business
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you should be able to

(1) “Connect the dots” and acquire a big picture of the key concepts for sustainability such as coupled humanenvironment
systems, triple bottom line, and the enabling operating mechanism such as ESG, CSR, SDGs by
UN, ISO (International standards), etc
(2) Deepen the understanding of sustainability as “human-environment system interaction with feedback loops” ,
inter-dependencies between ecosystems and business , challenges with ecoservices and public goods, and the
importance and role of institutions and culture to protect them
(3) Integrate the concept with real business world, learn a systematic methodology to assess, design & implement
sustainable transformation in the business for long term success, inclusive of identity & purpose, strategy,
capabilities, structure, processes, people practices & culture, change management

(4) Develop and practise skills through applying all above learning to analyze sustainability development of some
representative companies from various industries; and also creating own simulations to enable self-reflection
and reinforce the learning and application beyond the classroom
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction - The Big Picture

Ecosystem Services & Business -The Inter-dependencies

Public Goods & Protection -Role of Institutions and Culture

Sustainability in Business -The Framework for Transformation Change

Sustainable Transformation in Business -Start with identity & purpose

Sustainable transformation In the business -Sustainable strategy & business models

Sustainable transformation In the business -Capabilities, structure & people practices

Sustainable transformation In the business -Leadership & Culture

Sustainable transformation In the business - Operationalize sustainability: through process and reporting

Sustainable transformation In the business - Change management and stay resilient

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Managing Family Business
courses.description: Family business is a puzzling topic that fascinates academics, investors, and managers. These businesses are ridiculed, especially in Hong Kong, as unprofessional and cronyism-driven. But one cannot ignore their importance: families started many of the most successful firms in the world; families owned the majority of listed firms; many family firms uphold the best innovation, quality and brand value; and family funds constitute some largest philanthropic and investment projects. This course takes a family enterprising approach to discuss the importance, diversity, complexity, and more importantly continuous entrepreneurship of business family (as opposed to family business). Apart from lectures and case analysis, students should interact with family members and associated professionals to understand the types, life cycle, conflict, succession, characteristics of business families. For sustaining their growth, practical approaches, such as structures and procedures as advisory boards, family councils, family venture funds and spin-offs, and family philanthropy, will also be discussed. This course shall benefit family business members, managers in family-owned firms, and professionals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. to understand the nature, importance, and challenges to family businesses and continuance of family entrepreneurship
2. to study the basic models and theories, and key cases
3. to learn key management skills for working inside and working with family businesses
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Introduction: Leading growth & family entrepreneurship
(2) Family governance / Ownership structure
(3) Nurturing entrepreneurship in the next generation
(4) Family business strategies / Professionalization of family business
(5) Expanding the business / Institutional environment
(6) Family council / Family office
(7) Keeping, expanding, selling the business in the family / Stakeholders
(8) Estate planning, and private equity
(9) Family business advisory
(10) Family Philanthropy, Social Entrepreneurship, and Responsible Investment

In a typical session, the first hour will be an overview lecture on the Topic, or a discussion of the assigned Readings. A short 'Industry interlude' will cover aspects of the history and structure of the management consulting industry, including ethics, professional qualifications and recruitment practices. Students will be placed into groups and each group will be asked to practice specific consulting skills and roles, with opportunities for each student to plan a consulting engagement, facilitate discussions with clients, and lead a consulting team.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Management Decision Making
courses.description:
Making decision is a fundamental life skill. According to multiple sources, an adult makes about 35,000 decisions every single day. Some decisions are ‘no-brainers.’ Most decisions you’ll face are tough and complex with no easy or obvious solutions. Such decisions affect you, your family, friends, colleagues, work teams, organizations and many other known and unknown. An effective decision-making process may be more complicated than flipping a coin, tossing a dart or letting someone else to make a mediocre choice which depends on luck for success.

To understand the complexity and irrationality that arise in human decision making, you are going to answer many interesting questions in this course. Answers to these questions will shed light on your decision-making process and outcomes. Throughout the course journey of lectures, business cases and interactive exercises, you’ll scratch your heads and learn how to critically make life and work decisions with evidence and effective process.

(1) Understand the nature of human decision-making.
(2) How well can we trust ourselves in making decisions?
(3) Is timing a factor in quality decision-making?
(4) Build a solution-based decision-making.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: International Business
courses.description:
Both organizations and society are becoming increasingly global as developments in technology, media, and politics have made the world “smaller” and increasingly interdependent. While in the past the international arena has been limited to large multinational corporations and even some large companies have only been active in their local market, today increasingly many companies, both small and large, engage in business which transcends geographic, political, and cultural boundaries. Thus, for most firms international business is no longer an option it is a must.

Differences between countries such as cultural differences and institutional differences have important implications for the optimal way to conduct business in a country. Although the world is becoming more global, today more than ever people have an expectation that foreigners doing business in their country have an understanding of what management practices are normally used locally, and organizational behavior is still strongly influenced by people’s cultural background. To be successful in this global economy, a manager must understand the effect diverse cultures have on how organizations work and be capable of managing multiple cultures interacting—two skills this course will seek to develop. The course is highly interactive using case studies and simulations as well as interactive lectures and discussions to facilitate learning.

This course will help prepare people planning to work in large and small firms alike to be senior executives making important international business decisions and acting as an effective international manager. Most managers agree that international business is not easy. Thus, we will learn strategies to make the internationalization process easier, and we will develop an understanding of the different modes of entry which are at our disposal and when different modes are preferable. This course will also study mergers and acquisitions which are becoming increasingly important in our world today. The course will explore key strategies for international business and also investigate how to interact with people from different countries most effectively, how to work on multicultural teams effectively, how to be an effective leader in different countries, and how to conduct international negotiations. We will also study how to deal with complexity and deal with multiple tasks at the same time which is an important challenge that international managers face. The course will also explore key design, management, and strategy issues multinational companies face. While this course will focus on international business broadly, for part of the course we will take a deep dive into how to do business in mainland China as an example of international business. Thus, we will explore how to effectively enter and operate in China, how to negotiate effectively with Chinese, which strategies and management practices work best in China, how to be effective leader in China, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Develop an understanding of effective internationalization strategies
2. Learn the pros and cons of different entry modes
3. Learn about how to successfully design and manage important collaborative modes of international business like Mergers and Acquisitions.
4. Explore key strategies for international business
5. Acquire an understanding of how to interact with people from different countries most effectively including how to work on multicultural teams effectively
6. Develop an understanding of complex decision making in international business
7. Develop an understanding of how to be an effective leader in different countries
8. Learn how to conduct international negotiations effectively
9. Learn about key design, management, and strategy issues multinational companies face.
10. Learn key aspects of how to do business in mainland China

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Managing Innovation & Technology
courses.description: It’s an era of “Technology Everywhere”. The rapid advancement in technology literally impacts every sector of our society. From taxi services to mobile payment, from robotic engineering to artificial intelligence; new innovations and technology have laid substantial or even subversive changes to our ways of doing business. It is, therefore, important for senior management to understand the uncertainty and challenges engendered by technological and market changes, and with a better understanding, be able to derive the optimal ways to cope with these changes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking this course, students are expected to attain a good understanding of the innovation/entrepreneurship ecosystem (both local and overseas), innovation process & patenting, the emerging trend of technology, and the strategic choices for businesses and senior executives in order for them to succeed in this new “Technology Everywhere” era.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Tech Building Blocks
2. Mega Trends that Drive Tech Adoption
3. IP patenting & strategies
4. Strategies for managing innovation & technology (MNCs and SMEs)
5. Business Model Innovations
6. Start Up: Entrepreneurship vis-à-vis Intrapreneurship
7. X-preneurship: Attribute
8. Eco-system: A Lateral Perspective (Collaboration)
9. Eco-system: A Vertical Perspective (One to Many)
10. Eco-system: Hong Kong (the Role of Government; the recent Loop Project; the Greater South China Region)
11. Eco-system: Silicon Valley, Shenzhen, Singapore & Israel
12. Fintech/blockchain
13. Leadership model: to expect the unexpected
14. Disruptive technology

courses.title: Structural Equation Modeling
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to general linear structural equation models (SEMs). The topics treated include confirmatory factor analysis, path analysis, full SEMs, assessment of model fit, modification, multiple-group analysis, and applications in cross-cultural research. The goal is to provide a firm basis for continued study and research with SEMs.

courses.learning_outcomes:
- Students will have an overview of SEM applicable to the investigation of social science phenomena.
- Students will be equipped with the fundamental skills and concepts needed to understand and appreciate SEM.
- Students’ ability to evaluate the research of others will be enhanced.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Strategic Management
courses.description: Encountering an increasingly competitive business environment, how managers interpreting and responding to it is crucial to the success of a business. This course is designed to provide students with a concept of competition and an understanding of the role of managers in the process of strategy formulation, implementation, and evaluation. Major topics include organizational mission, analysis of business environment, strategic planning, formulation and implementation of strategies at both business and corporate level, strategic change, and strategic evaluation and control. Cases, in-depth readings, and contemporary issues will be discussed in the class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
1. explain the core strategic management concepts
2. understand the impacts of the internal and external environments of a firm on firm performance
3. apply analytical frameworks to define and analyze strategic problems; and to formulate and implement business strategies
4. explain the complex business opportunities and problems in a global context
5. demonstrate effective communication skills
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Formulating and implementing firm strategy
2. Strategic management theories and concepts
3. Business ethics in strategic decision-making
4. Strategy to address real life business opportunities and challenges
5. Nature of business competition and sources of competitive advantage
Other topics to be decided by course teacher

courses.title: Business Strategy
courses.description: This is a capstone course. Topics to be discussed include: programme strategy versus grand strategy, formulating business strategies, strategic choice, relations between business strategy and structure, strategic management of human resources, strategy evaluation and control, and the management of change. The course is conducted in an interactive and seminar style.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Strategic Management of Innovation
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide a solid grounding for students interested in top management and (to a lesser extent) government policy issues concerning the innovation process within organizations. The course is divided into several main parts. The first part discusses technology at the macro level: its impact on industries and nations, and patterns of technological change. The second part focuses on disruptive innovations – what they are, how they affect firms and industry change, and how they facilitate entrepreneurship. The third part deals with the response of firms to disruptive innovations, including the changing basis of competition in markets. The increasing returns environment is also examined. The fourth part focuses on building the internal capabilities of organizations to innovate, and discusses the innovator's solution. The fifth part discusses additional topics in innovation such as entrepreneurship and spurring innovation at the societal level. Case studies, both written and video-based, are used extensively to illustrate a range of technologies and the problems associated with developing them and bringing them to market. The course spends much time examining new technologies, how to think strategically about them, how to develop them and how firms should pursue them (or why they fail to pursue these new technologies).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will learn about the classic models of innovation and entrepreneurship as well as the exemplary cases of entrepreneurial success and failure. They will learn to develop a proposal for a new product or service. Students will also learn about the venture capital process.

Readings from Gary Hamel on entrepreneurship and innovation, Bringing Silicon Valley Inside (HBR). Other HBR readings also.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Seminar on China Business
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to provide students with in-depth understanding of how to do business in China with emphasis on marketing and management practice and issues in China. The course will also describe some of the contemporary approaches of business strategies in China. It is expected that students will attain marketing and management skills for doing business in China. Topics include: entry into China through J/V; choice of appropriate location to enter; human resources and infrastructure; changing environment of the China market; the impact of WTO accession on China; market entry strategies and key success factors; Chinese consumer characteristics and behavior patterns; marketing mix management in China; competition between international firms and the local ones; and adaptation and the relationship building process in China. The course is strengthened by studying many actual cases of companies doing business in China.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA
courses.learning_outcomes: This course aims at providing students with (1) conceptual understanding on what China business is and why it is so important in the contemporary business world, (2) hands-on practice in developing a realistic China business strategy (with focus on application) and (3) forging strategic leadership in China. Upon completion of this course, students are expected to have adequate knowledge and technical skills on China business, be able to formulate effective strategy for mainland China market with strategic leadership for execution. In addition to the traditional lecturing method, this course will include case analyses, pre-class assignments, group discussions, presentation and an action learning project.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Crafting and Executing Winning Strategies
courses.description: This is a capstone course that aims to equip executives with a strategic mindset and thinking about how to enhance and sustain firm competitiveness in the face of uncertainty and complexity. The focus will be on identifying the key drivers of persistent superior performance in different settings such that winning strategies can be crafted. Key topics to be discussed include strategic analysis, formulation of winning business and corporate strategies, strategy implementation, strategy evaluation and control, and strategy turnaround from external competitive dynamics and internal organizational dynamics. This course is conducted in an interactive and seminar style, with the use of a substantial amount of real life cases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be equipped with a strategic mindset and thinking about how to enhance and sustain firm competitiveness in the face of uncertainty and complexity.
2. Students will have insight in identifying the key drivers of persistent superior performance in different settings such that winning strategies can be crafted.
3. Students will acquire knowledge of strategic analysis, formulation of winning business and corporate strategies, strategy implementation, strategy evaluation and control, and strategy turnaround from external competitive dynamics and internal organizational dynamics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Strategic analysis
2. Formulation of winning business and corporate strategies
3. Strategy implementation
4. Strategy evaluation and control
5. Strategy turnaround from external competitive dynamics and internal organizational dynamics.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Advanced Social Psychology for Business Research
courses.description: This course is designed to survey the major theories and research in understanding human behaviors in social contexts. In the first two weeks, students will be required to learn about or re-familiarize themselves with classic theories and research in social psychology. In the remainder of the course, students will learn major theories that guide contemporary research in social psychology and how the theories can be used to generate novel hypotheses in business studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil/PhD students of Faculty of Business Administration
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of this course, students (1) should have acquired knowledge of major theories and methods in micro-level analysis of business behaviors, (2) will con-sider psychological variables in research, and (3) can generate psychological ex-planations in their own research.
courses.course_syllabus:
Classic theories and findings in Social Psychology I
Classic theories and findings in Social Psychology II
Theories about theory
Implicit theories
Theories of information processing
Theory of automaticity and goal pursuit
Motivational Theories I: Regulatory focus and regulatory fit
Motivational theories II – Epistemic motives, Fairness theories
Motivational theories III – Existential theories, Attachment theories
Social identity theorie
courses.feedback_evaluation: At the end of each class, students will be asked to answer a few questions related to the readings or the class discussion. This aims at gauging students’ learning of the materials. Performance on these tests accounts for **20%** of the final grade.
courses.required_readings: Hogg, M.A. & Vaughan, G.M. (2022). *Social psychology (9th ed.)*. Essex, England: Pearson.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Advanced Cultural Psychology for Business Research
courses.description: This course focuses on cultural influences on behaviors in business settings (marketing, management, financial decision making, and business ethics). We will first survey major cultural theories, and then discuss major cross-cultural differences revealed in self, attribution and social inferences, thinking and perceptual styles, emotion, and motivation. The aim is to understand how culture impacts business behaviors and how Asians may differ from individuals from other cultural background. This knowledge will lay a strong foundation for students to formulate business research in an emerging Asian Century.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil/PhD students of Faculty of Business Administration
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of this course, students should be able to (1) appreciate cultural influences on human psychology and behaviors, (2) understand scientific examination of cultural influences, and (3) consider culture as a variable in their research.
courses.course_syllabus:
WK1. Descriptive versus Explanatory Approach
WK2. Group versus Individual Processes
WK3. Dimensional Approaches
WK4. Origins of Cultural Differences: Universality versus Cultural-specificity
WK5. Self-representation
WK6. Self-enhancement
WK7. Attribution and Social Inferences
WK8. Thinking Styles
WK9. Perceptual and Mnemonic Styles
WK10. Emotion
WK11. Motivation
WK12. Multiculturalism & Cultural Mixing
WK13. Cultural Neuroscience

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Management Theory
courses.description: This seminar course introduces students to the foundations and applications of major management theories used in organizations and management. The course will begin with an overview of the theoretical paradigms in management and trace the development of influential management theories such as transaction cost theory, agency theory, institutional theory, resource based view, resource dependence theory, and organizational learning theory. The course covers seminal articles of each theory as well as its applications in the fields of management. The focus is on theory development, theorization of management phenomena, and theory extension.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Management
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students will be able to (1)develop a comprehensive understanding of major management theories; (2) apply the theories in organizational research; (3) extend the boundary of the theories to advanced management literatures.
courses.course_syllabus: The seminar covers the theoretical foundations and major streams of research in strategic management. In this sense, this seminar will serve as a *survey seminar*. More importantly, it seeks to train students to become informed researchers who will be able to contribute to the field of management.

2. Hoskisson, R., Hitt, M., Wan, W., & Yiu, D., 1999. Theory and research in strategic management: Swings of a pendulum. Journal of Management, 417-456.
3. Davis, G.F. and Marquis, C., 2005. Prospects for organization theory in the early twenty-first century: Institutional fields and mechanisms. *Organization Science*, *16*(4): 332-343.
4. Coase, R. 1937. The nature of the firm. *Economica* 4: 386-405.

6. Williamson, O. E. 1985. *The Economic Institutions of Capitalism.* Chapter 2 "Contractual Man": 43-67. New York: Free Press.

8. Madhok, A. 2002. Reassessing the fundamentals and beyond: Ronald Coase, the transaction cost and resource-based theories of the firm and the institutional structure of production. *Strategic Management Journal*, 23: 535–550.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Strategic Management and International Business
courses.description: This course is designed primarily for doctoral students to further their knowledge of theory and research of strategic management (SM) and international business (IB). In addition, the course is to help the participants enhance their capabilities for empirical studies in SM and IB and to facilitate the development of their personal research interests that will be incorporated into their research proposals. The course provides the participants an opportunity to be exposed to classic readings and the latest developments of theory and research issues in areas of SM and IB. In each class session participants are required to read a set of articles that are selected around a given topic and engage in discussions on the evaluation of respective theory and research methods. The course takes a seminar style and participants are required to read the articles assigned by the instructor prior to each class session and to actively participate in class discussions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Management
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students will be able to (1) understand the theory and research in the fields of strategic management and international business studies; (2) critically review the concepts and models of strategic management and international business; (3) apply the existing concepts and models to new research in the respective fields.

courses.required_readings: Recommended by the course instructor

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Research Methods in Strategic Management
courses.description: This course is meant for M.Phil and PhD students in the department of management. The purpose of this course is to introduce students to a variety of empirical approaches that are employed to investigate questions of interest in strategic management discipline as well as enable students learn about the relevance of the several methodologies that are widely used in the field. In this regard, the course will mainly discuss about the links between research questions and designs, and will also lay emphasis on how to review empirical research in strategic management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil/ PhD Programmes in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn how to review empirical papers
2. Learn about the application of empirical techniques to test research questions
3. Learn basic ideas behind the various regression approaches and their uniqueness
courses.course_syllabus:
Papers from a variety of sources. For example, published papers from network of popular economics and sociology journals, including papers from mainstream journals in management discipline (such as SMJ, OS, JIBS, Research Policy, AMJ, ASQ, and others).

Topics to be covered:

1. Foundations of empirical research in strategy
2. Theories, variable constructs, models, and hypotheses testing
3. Correlations and Causality
4. Cross-sectional designs
5. Nature of dependent variables and regression analyses
a. Continuous variables – OLS regressions, generalized linear models, seemingly unrelated regressions, Tobit regressions
b. Dichotomous variables – Logistic regression, Probit regression, Rare-events logistic regression
c. Limited dependent variables (Count variables) – Poisson models, Negative binomial, Zero inflated binomial
d. Fractional variables
e. Truncated regression models
6. Time-series and panel designs; variance decomposition method
7. Difference-in-differences techniques
8. Quasi-experimental designs in strategy research
a. Regression discontinuity designs
b. Natural experiments
9. Lab experiments and simulations in strategy research
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
courses.required_readings: Research papers from major journals and other readings that explain the research methods or illustrate how the research methods are being employed in strategic management research are adopted as course readings.
courses.recommended_readings: Econometric Analysis of Cross Section and Panel Data by Jeffrey Wooldridge

courses.description: The Leadership Development course will create the opportunity for students to reflect on two key areas of leadership; managing themselves (self awareness and understanding) and managing relationships (the impact they have on others). courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Leading Organizations
courses.description: Effective managers must not only develop winning strategies, but they must also implement them. To do so, managers have to understand the full complexity of organizations, adopt effective tactics, and apply appropriate tools to get things done. The main purpose of this course is to prepare students to successfully lead organizations and their units. This entails developing knowledge and skills to analyze key issues in organizational structure, power and influence, culture, change, and governance.

3. begin to build a repertoire of strategies and tactics to increase their effectiveness in varied situations, induce and lead change initiatives, and use politics in pragmatic ways to get things done.

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Creating Self-efficacy and Impact on Communication
courses.description:
Theories will stay on paper forever if they are not applied in practice. To become a successful business leader in the future, you need to master the skills of effective communication and be able to communicate with impact. Contrary to popular myth, there is no natural outstanding presenter or inborn good communicator. This course will help you acquire the necessary skills of a great communicator and break your psychological barrier when you need to present in front of a large audience.

Unlike the other presentation workshops, we are not training for elocutionists. In this course, you will learn how to master the golden rules of communication in the real world and how to adopt a target audience based impactful dialogue to achieve your goal with long-term sustainable business impact. These audience groups may include investors, bosses, business partners and other business stakeholders.

Delivering an eloquent presentation in a story-telling way is only the first step. This course will also enhance your probing skills of obtaining useful information from business stakeholders, winning the pitches, handling objections and coping with Q&As. More importantly, you will learn how to close a deal at the end of the communication/presentation based on experiential learning and introduction of various effective and relevant models deduced from real working and business situations.

The course will also introduce escalator pitch which has become popular and is a critical skill nowadays. When successfully deployed, it will improve your bargaining power and the chance of winning. Lecturers will share with you their personal experience using real cases from MNCs such as Procter & Gamble, Unilever, Nestle, PepsiCo, Johnson & Johnson and Dyson.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) maneuver and internalize the taught skills in a comprehensive, contemporary, competent and confident (4Cs) way; and
(2) plan, prepare and practice (3Ps) effective communication, which is a useful and practical tool for both of students' career and academic advancement.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Structure a communication
(2) Storytelling presentation
(3) Three hottest applications
(4) Escalator pitch
(5) Handling objections & coping with Q&As
(6) Wrapping up techniques
(7) How to communicate to the Board
(8) How to do an outstanding impactful communication with media

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Design Thinking for Business Innovation
courses.description:
The purpose of this course is to help students understand what design thinking is all about--- its relationship to creativity and innovation and how it can be applied to foster experience and business model innovation.

This class concentrates in the adoption of ethnographic, visualization and brainstorming techniques and modeling frameworks to complement conventional market research, decision tree, and SWOT analysis. Gamification of customer experience, co-creation with customers, and the design of an experience network will be the main emphasis of our study.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, the students will be able to conduct user and business model researches, understand the design process for enriching the customer experience with a sustainable business model, and perform tests to validate the results.

同學將會在修畢本學科後學懂如何從事用戶研究和商業模式研究，了解如何利用設計思維及商業模式來深化客戶體驗，達致可持續並可驗證的結果。

(1) A Hands-on Guide to Human-centered Design
(2) Gamification of the Experience Network
(3) The Hear (Inspiration) Stage
(4) The Create (Ideation) Stage
(5) The Deliver (Implementation) Stage
(6) Interim Presentation of User Research Findings
(7) From Product Development to Customer Development
(8) Business Model Generation
(9) Customer Engagement and Validation
(10) Putting Everything Together

courses.subject: MGNT
courses.title: Digital Transformation and Innovation
courses.description:
Digital transformation and innovation has become an integral part of every corporate's business strategy, if they are to remain competitive even as industry incumbents now. However, complications surface when executives have to align where to invest - digital transformation to drive operational efficiencies, customer experience, or new products and services, as well as incremental innovation, or disruptive innovation.

This course introduces practical frameworks and key elements to guide the thought process behind assessment and formation of a digital transformation and innovation strategy. Strong emphasis would be on digital customers and their implications to different consumer-facing industries, from the lens of incumbent corporations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MBA in Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) understand the key levers of digital and innovation;
(2) assess the role of digital and innovation given the maturity of an industry and opportunities/ threats imposed on an incumbent corporation; and
(3) formulate strategy to roadmap and extract values from digital and innovation transformation programmes
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) An Executive Brief: from Technology Landscape to Industry Transformation
(2) The New Normal: From New Products and New Services, to New Intelligence and New Experience
(3) Reinvention of Businesses Driven by Digital Platform & Ecosystem
(4) Structuring for Digital Transformation and Innovation
(5) Innovation from Industry Experts Series
